title: Sinusoidal Function Modeling - Windmill - Part A

content.description:
The blades of a windmill rotate in a clockwise direction and complete one rotation every <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>6</mn> </math> seconds. Point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>B</mn> </math> is on the tip of one of the windmill blades and is located directly above the center of the windmill at time <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbdfgBPjMCPbqedmvETj2BSbqefm0B1jxALjhiov2DaebbnrfifHhDYfgasaacH8Xr=y0tbbg9q8qqaqpepec8Eeeq0tXdbba9frFj0=OqFL0dbba9LqpC0db9Fve9pce9v8qqaq=dir=xirpG0tb9fr=xfr=xfrpeWZqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaqaaqaaaOqaaiaadshacqGH9aqpcaaIWaaaaa@3901@</annotation> </semantics> </math> seconds, as indicated in the figure. Point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>B</mn> </math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>40</mn> </math> meters from the center of the windmill. The center of the windmill is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>75</mn> </math> meters above the level ground. As the windmill blades rotate at a constant speed, the distance between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>B</mn> </math> and the ground periodically decreases and increases.

The sinusoidal function <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>h</mn> </math> models the distance between <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>B</mn> </math> and the ground, in meters, as a function of time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>t</mn> </math>, in seconds.
content.question:
Part A

The graph of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>h</mn> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>,</mo> <mi>h</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C87@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for the five points:   <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math> .

Moving from left to right:

Point F is at a maximum point.

Point G is on the midline.

Point J is at a minimum point.

Point K is on the midline.

Point P is at a maximum point.

frqParts.text:
Part A

The graph of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>h</mn> </math> and its dashed midline for two full cycles is shown. Five points, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math>, are labeled on the graph. No scale is indicated, and no axes are presented.

Determine possible coordinates <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>,</mo> <mi>h</mi> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C87@</annotation> </semantics> </math> for the five points:   <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>F</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>G</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>J</mn> </math>, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>K</mn> </math>, and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>P</mn> </math> .

Moving from left to right:

Point F is at a maximum point.

Point G is on the midline.

Point J is at a minimum point.

Point K is on the midline.

Point P is at a maximum point.

topic.text: 3.7: Sinusoidal Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Construct equivalent graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations of functions that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context, with and without technology.
